description.narrative: The intervention is expected to contribute directly to the reduction of poverty and vulnerability by accelerating business solutions relevant for poor people. The project promotes gender equality through gender-sensitive investment design and impact assessment studies. It also contributes to environmental sustainability by eventually supporting investment projects that create environmental benefits and promote climate change mitigation (e.g, in the area of renewable energy).The intended outcome is increased inclusive business investments in ADB's development member countries brought about through (i) improvements in the commercial viability, business models, and social impact of inclusive business opportunities; and (ii) enhanced investment climates and ecosystems for inclusive business.

Projektet avser underlätta för inkluderande företag i Asien att direkt bidra till minskad fattigdom & utsatthet genom kapacitetsutveckling av företag som skapar nya arbetstillfällen för människor som lever i fattigdom genom att inkludera dem i sina värdekedjor.Projektet ska också stödja regeringar & banker att främja inkluderande affärsmodeller & privatsektorledd fattigdomsminskning.

The project will facilitate for inclusive business in Asia in order to contribute directly to reduction of poverty and vulnerability, through capacity development to inclusive business models that create new decent jobs for people in poverty by including them into their value chains. It will also help governments and banks to foster inclusive business and private sector driven poverty reduction.

description.narrative: The intervention, Inclusive Business (IB) Support, was started in 2013 and ended in 2018, with the support from the Embassy/Sida (20 MSEK), Credit Suisse ($0.1 million) and the ADB ($0.4 million). Later, the GIZ joined as a co-financing partner with $0.197 million, increasing the total budget to $3.797 million. After four and a half years of its implementation, the results achieved against the results framework are: At the outcome level, the number of IB projects supported by the ADB's Private Sector Operations Department (PSOD) has gradually increased since 2014. Total of 18 new ADB nonsovereign projects, classified based on certain filtering by the PSOD, were approved during 2014-2017, exceeded the target of 15 new projects. The total funding committed amounted to $1,044 million. Furthermore, ADB introduced Fast Approach to Small Non-sovereign Transactions (FAST) to facilitate funding of small IB projects. This approach facilitates ADB to finance small projects but highly development transactions, particularly in poorer countries and in softer sectors such as agribusiness, social infrastructure, and micro-finance. Five transactions were tagged as IB out of seven non-sovereign transactions so far since the introduction of FAST in 2015. At the output level, the intervention provided support for pre- and post-investment to 41 companies which far exceeded the target 20 companies. However, only 3 due diligence assessments were done against the target of 13 targets (output 1). Ex ante impact assessment tools (output 2) was development to primarily measure the social impact and the inclusiveness of business approaches on targeted Bottom of Pyramid (BoP) sectors (including women), and to identify opportunities and strategies to help the business maximize its social impacts. However, only three (out of four targets) ex ante impact assessment studies was conducted as the companies often already had the baseline information, and assessing the impact would required about five years. In terms of increase awareness of IB and its enabling environment among governments and business associations in selected DMCs and sectors (output 3), eight sectors studies covering six key sectors (energy, textile, housing, sanitation, agriculture and financing), which served as preparatory materials for subsequent in-country sector workshops. In terms of knowledge development (output 4), IB was promoted in among IB investment communities and development partners in Asia and the Pacific. For example, the second IB Asia Forum brought about 400 practitioners at ADB Headquarters in February 2016 for discussion on innovative private sector solutions to job creation and services/goods provision to BoP, and the role of governments for supporting a better IB enabling environment. In addition, there were also various references/publications on IB produced, the in-country workshops, presentations, and international foras that put ADB at the forefront of IB proportion in the region. In addition, the intervention was instrumental in promoting IB in regional foras, such as Asian-Pacific Economic Cooperation (APEC) and Association of Southeast Asian Nations (ASEAN). The intervention contributed to putting IB on the development agenda in the Asia-Pacific and ASEAN regions through collaboration with APEC and the ASEAN. As a result, joint ministerial and leaders statements issued by both bodies in 2017 include directives for IB promotion and support in member countries. During the ASEAN Summit in 2017, the ASEAN Coordinating Committee on Micro, Small, and Medium Enterprises adopted the proposal to integrated IB in the ASEAN Strategic Action Plan for Small and Medium Enterprise Development. Interms of gender aspects, the study "How Inclusive is Inclusiev Business for Woman? Examples from Asia and Latin America" was carried out. Teh findings suggest that inclusive businesses are indeed bringing positive changes to the lives of women in Asia and that by addressing gender-based constraints, these models are yielding business benefits as well.
No indicator available - only a description of the activity results is published
